timeline.message:
Rename Tile -> TileSource

TileSource better captures what this object represents--some URL and eventually file path that points to a file that contains tileset data that we can render on the map as an overlay. The old name, Tile, suggests that the object represents a single tile, at a single zoom level, while the tileset files we use actually are pyramidal and contain tiles at multiple zoom levels.

timeline.bodyText: Naming nit: You download tiles from a tile source, so maybe this would make more sense as "downloadTiles"?
timeline.author: gino-m

replies.bodyText:
Fair point. I guess the "Tile > TileSet" renaming issue isn't really a duplication then.
One could argue that we are in fact downloading the tile source--we're simply copying the file specified at a given URL (the tile source). We don't really know anything about individual tiles or care about them until we get down to the tile provider level, which looks at tiles specified in a tile source.
But I also don't want to argue semantics--if it's clearer to use "Tiles" or "TileSet" here I think that's fine--technically speaking though, if we are calling the thing specified in the geoJSON a tile source, that is what we are downloading here--that is, we aren't doing any parsing of the contents of the tile source and downloading individual tiles, we are just downloading the source file itself whole cloth. @gino-m
replies.author: scolsen

replies.bodyText: Ahhh... sorry, at first glance I may have though this was actually downloading the tiles themselves. Please disregard, this makes perfect sense. If we really wanted to future-proof our semantics, we could define "tile source" to be an arbitrary way of getting tiles, and this case as an "mbtiles tile source's geojson extents file" but we can cross that bridge if we ever get to it.
replies.author: gino-m

timeline.bodyText: Same comment here - the issue isn't that tiles couldn't be download from the tile source, so I'd still expect this to be a TileDownloadException.

timeline.bodyText: This case is a little be trickier - it's not clear how to describe that we're "getting all tile sources for which all tiles have been downloaded", so I think it's ok as-is.
